sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: This is Ruth Bayhylle. The date today is June 20 [2011]. I am in the offices of the United American Indian Involvement on Sixth Street in Los Angeles [California], speaking with LeRoy Big Soldier. LeRoy, when and where were you born?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: In [unclear] ,Germany, March 22, 1954. My dad was stationed out there. He was in the service, U.S. Army, army hospital, I guess.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: So your dad was in the service. Did your mother work there as well?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: My mom was at home, I mean in Wisconsin, in Black River Falls, so he [unclear] her. He asked the army, I guess, “Can I [unclear] my wife?” “Yeah, go ahead.” So she went to Germany. She was already pregnant by then. I guess it would happen any day now. She couldn’t hold me in, so I was born [unclear].

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: What tribe are you?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Ho-Chunk.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Are you full?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Where’s your reserve? Where’s your home?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Black River Falls.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Black River Falls?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Wisconsin, reservation.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: That’s a reservation then, Black River Falls Reservation.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: They call it BRF.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: How many brothers and sisters did you have?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Four brothers, four sisters.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Were you the oldest or middle or—

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Oldest.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Did you ever actually live at Black River Falls?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: As a baby.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Did you go to school there at all?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Never. Been out at California all of my life.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: When did you come to California then?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: I don’t know.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: You remember the year or how old you were?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: In the sixties.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: In the sixties?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: I think so.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: How did you get out to California then? Tell me about that.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Well, I guess I flew out here, I guess.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: What did you come out here for? With your parents?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, my mom and dad wanted to move, relocate, go somewhere else or something. I guess there was no jobs over there, I guess.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: You were born in Germany. Then when did your family move back to the United States?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: I don’t know. May. I don’t have it on me, but it was May something.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: How old were you, or how many years?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: I was a couple months.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: So you were in Germany and then you moved back to the United States when you were just a baby?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, a couple months, I guess.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Where did you live when you came back to the United States?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: I lived out there, I guess, Black River.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: So you did live there?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, we was going to fly back there, but there was no airplane available, so we just came on a boat from Germany. That’s a long ride there.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Yes, that’s a long way. Your father and your mother and you, right?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Was your father from Black River Falls?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: And your mother too?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: I think from Madison.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Is she Ho-Chunk, too, you said?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, full-blooded.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: So you were born in Germany and after a few months you moved back to the United States with your mother and father. You moved back to Black River Falls?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, for a while.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Then where did you go?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: That’s when we came out here to Los Angeles.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: So you were just a baby then when your family came out.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Did you ever speak to your parents, or your father and your mother, about relocation and how that worked for them?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Not talked a lot. I think they just got tired of Wisconsin, I guess.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: What was the problem back there?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: No jobs, I guess.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: That’s a big problem, yeah.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Or the snow and all that, I guess.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: What kind of work did your father do?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Custodian. Yeah, custodian, janitor, work away from—

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: He had been in the army, though, right? Did he have any training or a trade that he could [unclear]?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, they put him behind a desk, but I guess he didn’t like that. He did that, like, sixteen years. He regrets that now. Only it made us a living because he wanted out. They put him behind a desk pushing a pencil. He didn’t want to do that. All those battlefields he went to, of course, everybody wanted to hear the war stories, and he could tell a story. I mean, he wouldn’t talk to us, but when he’s drinking, then he’ll talk. He said he went through hell. He said, “I just got [unclear].” It was rough on them. A lot men that went in there, a lot of them, they didn’t come back.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: So he didn’t really have a trade then, really, did he, other than maybe clerical work, filing and typing?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, in the army. Well, recruiting. I guess that’s what he was doing, but he got tired of that.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: So you decided to come out to California. So did you and your family actually come out on the relocation program through BIA [Bureau of Indian Affairs]?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: How old were you then when you came out to L.A.?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: I don’t remember. I must have been a baby when we came out here to Los Angeles. That’s the only place we’ve been living, L.A., all the time, California.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Tell me what you remember. Where did you live when you came to Los Angeles most of the time? I mean you probably moved around a lot, but where did you live? What parts of town did you live in?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: What parts of town? Used to live out on 25 and Hoover. I remember that pretty good. 1963, ’62, that’s when the [Watts] Riots broke out, 25th and Hoover. Of course, they tore it down, but I remember that, 25th and Hoover.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Did you go to school there then, too, public school?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, yeah, [unclear] Elementary.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Did you live in an apartment house or a house?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: An apartment, two-story.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Were there any other Indian families in the apartment?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: I think we were the only one.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: When you were growing up then, did you meet any other people that came out on relocation? Do you remember?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: No, I don’t remember, not really. My mom and dad’s Indian friends come over.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Her Indian friends?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, come over and visit. They were Indians too.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Did your mother work?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: She was, like, a house mom or house mom.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Where did she work?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: At home, just watch the kids when my dad goes to work.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: So she stayed home and took care of the house and the children.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: So you went to school. You lived on 25th and Hoover. That’s the first place you remember, is that right?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: And then you went to one of the elementary schools there, is that right? Did you ever go away to boarding school anywhere?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: You went to public school in Los Angeles.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, always.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Where did you go to high school then?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Belmont High School, 1971. I was seventeen years old then. I remember that, but I started drinking and party, whatever. Had to drop out. My dad took me over there. “Bring your dad or somebody with you.” I got way behind. There was no way I could catch up, so I had to do continuation, but I didn’t do that either. That was a big thing in those days.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: High school and graduation? High school diploma?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah. I regret that when I look back at it. I was young. I didn’t know nothing, seventeen years old. That was 1971.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Well, you can always go back in the continuation school.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, I mean, I already got my high school diploma. That was 1990 I got it.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Good. How did that work? Where did you go to get it?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Here.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: You attended Central High?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, Central High School. 1990, got my GED and I went, “Oh, it’s even harder.” All it is is one book. All that time I didn’t know that. I kept going back and kept failing.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Kept what?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: I was failing. I didn’t make it. I was a couple points behind, so I had to go back again. Three, the charm. I made it.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Third time you did it.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, got the GED.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Good for you, LeRoy. That’s good.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah. so I might as well get my high school diploma too.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Yeah.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: They told me [unclear] one course.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: One course to get your diploma?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah. He says, “You got enough credits.” He said, “Want to do that?” “Yeah, I might as well. That’s better than—.” Because they want to see your high school diploma, your GED. A high school diploma, I still got it.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: So then where have you worked when you were living here in Los Angeles? What kind of work did you do?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Shipping and receiving, security, security guard, I guess. Worked out there in Redondo Beach, 1985 to ’88. I got laid off over there. They were laying off the—so I was there five more years, the longest. They would have kept me, but they let everybody go. Under five years, they let everybody go. So I was there, like, three years. “Two more years, we would have kept you. But sorry, we’ve got to let you go.”

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Gee.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: I collect unemployment for a while.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: You collected unemployment?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, for a while.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: At least you were able to do that for a little bit. And then where did you go to work?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: I worked here and there, also doing security. When I was out here in L.A., I don’t how many places I worked. Well, some places I didn’t like or—security.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Yeah, it didn’t work.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: It didn’t work out, so I quit there and go somewhere else, just moved around.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Did you get married and have a family? Do you have children?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, I had girlfriends and all that. Not that I know of. I don’t think I got any kids, I don’t think.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: You don’t have any children, but you did have friends and a girlfriend.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, a girlfriend, yeah, back then.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Did you ever go to any of the powwows or any of the dances that they had around here in town?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Oh, yeah, all the time. Yeah.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Did you meet a lot of Indians there? Any Indians that had come out on relocation that you know of?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: I never asked them.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Never came up, huh?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: I wanted to ask about your family, your mother and your father. What kinds of things did they do for social activities or for fun? Did they go to church or did they go to the Indian dances?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, used to go to church.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: What church did they go to, do you remember?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: I don’t remember. It used to be here, downtown, I guess. Yeah, it’s still there. That was back in 1960s.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: What church? On what street maybe?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Christian church, 6th and [unclear].

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: What’s the name of it?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: I don’t know, some Christian church.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: The church on 6th Street.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, 6th and—what was that street? I walk by there all the time. That’s on this side of town, like 6th and Town, right on the corner. But I remember that. [unclear], quit coming about a week ago there. I remember he used to pick us up, take us home. He was good to us, that reverend. I forget the name, but that was 1963, ’64, something like that.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: It was on 6th Street?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, 6th and Town, downtown? Something like that. I forget the other street.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: How long did you go to that church, do you think, you and your family?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Oh, like, a year.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: How many?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: A year. It wasn’t that long.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Did you live in the area? Was it close by?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, that’s when we used to live on 25th and Hoover. He used to come and pick us up in the van, give us food, whatever. They were real good to us.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Were a lot of Indians going to that church?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, there were some Indians there. Yeah.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: That’s good.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: I don’t know what happened. I guess Mom and Dad—I don’t know if they got bored with that or something, because they didn’t want us to go no more. We quit going. Oh, no, that’s when we had to move, yeah.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Oh, you had to move out of the area.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: We had to move to Glendale. Not Glendale. What’s that by Belmont High School? I guess that’s L.A. or—

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Echo Park? Elysian Park?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, around that area. So we had to move, so we quit going.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: It was far away then at that point, right?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Where did you go to school when you moved to Echo Park or that area?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: I was going to Virgil High School on Vermont.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: What was that like?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Oh, it was all right. I didn’t care for that either. I was drinking then.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: You were drinking already by then?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: So you were how old? Fifteen? Thirteen?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Something like that, yeah.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: When did you start drinking, do you think? How old were you?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Oh, when I was a teenager, twelve, thirteen years old. I was in a foster home. That was 1967, ’68.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Oh, my gosh.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, we tried to keep two brothers together in a foster home and everything. I stayed out there, I don’t know, like, two years.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: You and your brother?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, my brother. Picked us up. My older sister used to pick us up. Of course, we’d be drinking, “Want a beer?” “Yeah.” [unclear], but I denied it. I said, “I’m not no drunk. I can’t be. I’m too young,” or whatever.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: So you had a pretty hard life.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, but I’ve been sober a long time now, like twenty years, twenty-five years.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: That’s good. Congratulations. That’s good.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: I don’t smoke no weed. I don’t smoke any cigarettes. I quit smoking too. I haven’t done that yet.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: What kind of work are you doing now, LeRoy?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: I ain’t doing nothing. I look here and there, look for work, but I don’t know. I went to Children’s Hospital recently, like a month ago or something. My sister-in-law, she works there. She’s married to my brother. Lots of family in that. She told me that, “You should go back over there, fill another one out.”

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Yeah, you should. Just keep going back.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: They opened up that new building a month ago, next month, so I might try that out.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Yeah, if they need more staff.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Got no record, so you got clean record. That’s the first thing they check on you, do a background on you. Not no killer or somebody.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: You should. I would if I were you. Just keep going back.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: [unclear] going out there this week [unclear] some money [unclear].

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Have you ever talked to anyone else that came out of relocation? Do you have any friends who came out on relocation, their families?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Indians?

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Uh-huh.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: I probably have, but I don’t remember.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: I mentioned that I’ve spoken to quite a few people that came out, and some people had a pretty good time, pretty good experience, and other people really struggled. Sounds like your family struggled a little bit when they came out here. Why was that, do you think?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Well, I don’t know. Maybe the environment or economy, I guess. Like I say, he talked about going back to the service again, but he never did that, though. I mean he could have gone back in. He could have, but I guess he didn’t want to.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: What kind of work did he do here in Los Angeles then?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Custodian, making pretty good money doing that, working over here at the—still over there, Triple-A, Adams and [unclear].

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Right. The [unclear] Building.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: That’s still there. I remember that. Used to go over there, pick up his check with my mom and dad. My mom and my sister, we’d go pick his check up, cash it and pay the rent, get groceries or whatever. Yeah, I remember that, ’63. Oh, that’s when the riots broke out, the race riots. I was looking out the window, looking out there, and it was deserted. I’d never seen it like that.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: It was what?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Deserted. Couldn’t see nobody.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Where were you living?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Twenty-fifth and Hoover, second floor, looking out the window. National Guard, I guess, had machine guns, .50-caliber, the kind of gun they had back in the—

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Wow.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Nobody on the street.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Wow. What happened then? How did you spend the day? Did you stay inside?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Stay inside, eat, watch TV, whatever. Couldn’t go outside. Mom and Dad said, “You guys can’t go outside because of that riot.”

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Yeah, because that would have been just down south from where you were.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, it was on Vermont.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Vermont and Adams, south of Adams and—

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Rioting right there, yeah, right in there. You heard gunfire going off. Lots of cops, mostly National Guard, I guess. But I remember that.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Wow. How old were you?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Nine?

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Gee.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Born in 1954. Yeah, I was about nine, I guess, eight or nine.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: What did your parents think about the riots? Did they say?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: [unclear].

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: They didn’t think it was anything? But it scared them enough to make you stay inside, didn’t it?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, we had to. Couldn’t go nowhere. That was boring.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: You have an older sister, you said, that took care of a lot of things.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, she passed away, though. When was that? 2010 or ’09.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Oh, so just recently. You were the oldest boy, is that right?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: But she was the oldest of the children then, right?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah. My other sister’s still living, the other one.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Where does she live?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Hawthorne [unclear] Wisconsin. The other one lives in Bakersfield. She used to live in Wisconsin, too, but [unclear]. I guess it wasn’t working out in Wisconsin, so she went to Arizona with my niece, and I guess things didn’t work out. They got bored over there, so she moved out here.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: She lives in Bakersfield now?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: What’s her name?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Edith.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: So all of the children, you and all the rest of them, your older sisters, all your sisters were born out here in Los Angeles then, is that right?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, pretty sure. Oh, except for my older sister. She was born out there.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: She was born in Wisconsin.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: I don’t remember, Black River, maybe Black River, I guess, but I know she was born out there. That’s when we came out here, I think, when she was born. I forgot what year that was.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: I’m trying to get this straight. When you came out here, there was your father and mother, your older sister—

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: And me, yeah.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Just the four of you, or was there another one?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: No, that was it, and the rest of my brothers and sisters all born out here in L.A., yeah.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Did your parents ever talk about the trip out on relocation? How did they get out here, do you know?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Oh, I don’t know. I guess we flew out here, I guess.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: I think we flew out here.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: You flew out?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: I think so.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Was your father still in the service then when he came out?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: No, he was out.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: That’s what you said. He never went back in.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, he was talking about going back in because I guess they wanted to take him back, but he didn’t want to go. I don’t know. I don’t guess he felt comfortable behind a desk pushing a pencil.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Just a few more, LeRoy, a few more questions. Tell me about living in Los Angeles, what that’s been like for you. First of all, have you ever lived anywhere else?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, I lived out in Utah. My brother used to live out there. St. George, I guess, Pima Reservation. Oh, man, that was party-hardy out there back in the seventies.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: That’s in Arizona?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: No, Utah.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: That was the Pima—

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: I don’t mean Utah.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Arizona?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, Utah, yeah, St. George, on the outskirts of the Indian reservation, Pima Reservation.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Really, in Utah?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Pima Reservation?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Not Pima. I mean the Paiute. I get it mixed up. Yeah, it’s Paiute. [unclear] to go out there.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: And stay?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: You would just drink, get into fights, whatever, go to jail, back in the day. That didn’t work out. I lived there for a while, two, three months. Got tired of it and came back to L.A., and my brother followed. He had a couple of kids then. In 1975, I remember [unclear] used to work at the [unclear]. [unclear] my mom and dad.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: What guy?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Some Indian guy. Fuddemaker. He’s the same tribe we are.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Oh, yeah, John, John Fuddemaker, uh-huh.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: LeRoy Chase, he worked over there, too. He said, “Hey, I used to help your mom and dad with the bills and that.” He said, “I used to work with your brother.” I thought he was kidding, and my brother was already working there, my brother John. I said, “Really?” He said, “Yeah. Hey, come in Monday, man, and I’ll put you to work, help your mom and dad with the bills. Come on in Monday.”

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: So what happened?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: They hired me. I got hired.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: What did you do there?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Janitor, moving, sweeping, mopping. It was easy enough. Had to move stuff. I lived on Fifth and Hill. Oh, man, we had to go up those steps. There was no elevator. We had to take everything up those steps.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Fifth and Hill, right.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, right by the Pussycat Theater. I remember that.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Above the Pussycat Theater.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Next to it. I thought they closed that down, but I don’t think it was [unclear]. I don’t think it was [unclear]. But I remember that. Oh, man, those steps were wood. [unclear]. We had [unclear] tabletops and everything.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Oh, gosh. Where were you taking it?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Over there, Washington. They were relocating. I remember that. I was sober, though. Made us the hamburgers, whatever. I made good money. That’s [unclear]. We had to move them over there, relocate, and that was something. I remember that, 1975.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: How long did you work for the Indian Center?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: A month.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: That’s good. That was a good job for you.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, Friday, weekends. I was going to school there, too, but I dropped out, trying to get my high school diploma.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Here at UAII?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: No, over there at the Indian Center. It had to be ’75 because we went there nine months, but I dropped out of that too, started drinking, and so I left my class with that. I learned a lady got murdered [unclear].

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: A lady got murdered? Where?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, lesbians. [unclear] any girls [unclear].

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: When was that? Who was that, do you remember?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: That was in ’75. Yeah, she chopped her head off.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Oh, that’s right. I remember that.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: I remember that.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Here arms too.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: I think so. Yeah, she got jealous, messing around behind her back, and she didn’t like it. She was a tutor there, a teacher there.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Oh, my gosh. At the Indian Center?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, she killed her, murdered her.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: I didn’t remember that.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, I remember that. Oh, man, I couldn’t believe that. Her? Chopped her up, killed her. Worked as a teacher. [unclear] for murder.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Gosh.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, [unclear] believed it.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: That was a wild time back then, wasn’t it, seventies, sixties and seventies?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: [unclear] pretty girl. [unclear] Seventh and Hoover.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Was that where the bar was, Seventh and Hoover?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Because they were right next to each other, weren’t they?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: [unclear] drink there too, got into fights. My brother was a bouncer there, my brother John. He met these other people there. Then we’d get tired there. Closing time, go downtown to Shrimpo, down to Shrimpo. [unclear] used to be cops there, but [unclear] fighting, raising hell, throwing bottles, having powwows, pick up women, whatever, make a run, pass out in a van.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Oh, my gosh.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: [unclear] how we got home. I don’t remember. Drove home. [unclear] driven home by somebody. I don’t even remember leaving there. Sometimes I’ll be in a van and wake up next morning. Everybody’s gone, of course. I don’t remember what happened. That was back in the day, though. Well, I guess [unclear]. My brother went to a program. I don’t remember. It was the late seventies, I guess. [unclear] over here on Pico in Westlake. So I go there. My brother was in there. They’re telling me I was alcoholic. I didn’t want to hear it. They said, “Oh, doing this program helps,” just like he was, but he started going to prison then in [unclear]. He ended up twice. Used to go visit him. [unclear]. “Oh, that’s what I hear.” [unclear] guy pushed my dad, and my dad’s kind of old. Pushed him or something, and I guess [unclear]. My brother jumped him, and this other Indian guy jumped him too. So my dad kicked him and [unclear] from there. I wasn’t there. [unclear] attempted murder.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Whoa.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, so my brother beat the shit out of him. He almost died, [unclear] assault with deadly weapon, ADW. In the county jail here downtown. The county jail. I’d go visit him. He was there, like, nine months. My daddy was in there. I couldn’t come up with the bail money to get him out, so that was hard for me. [unclear]. He was in there for nine months, god. They wouldn’t let him go because they said he was an accessory. So I guess my brother talked to the D.A., or what’s his name, whoever that was. I forgot. He said, “I want to take the blame for everything. My dad didn’t do it.” He says, “I’ll take the whole thing. I don’t care. I’ll go to prison, but I want my dad out of here.” So I guess they finally dropped the charges on my dad, let him go.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: After nine months, jeez.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: I think it was nine months. A long time. We used to go visit him almost every weekend, give him cigarettes. That’s when they used to let you smoke, so we gave him a carton of cigarettes. [unclear] in there, here and there.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: You were working?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: I was sober, though. My brother said, “I don’t care what happens to me. Send me into San Quentin, whatever. I want my dad out of here.” Damn, I could not come up with the money. They wanted that bail money. It was a lot of money in those days. It was, like, a thousand dollars—

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Oh, wow.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: —because of the charge he was on, attempted murder.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Assault with a deadly weapon.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: [unclear] attempted murder.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: First, yeah.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: [unclear] going to get them all. They let that other guy go or he got cleared, I guess. I was in Arizona when that happened, so I don’t know. He went to [unclear] then, and they went back again and decided he [unclear] saw the light or whatever, sobered up. I noticed a difference in him.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: You noticed a difference in him?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, the second time. I guess first time, I guess he didn’t see [unclear]. I mean that’s how it’s going to be, go to prison, back and forth, back and forth, wind up getting killed or whatever. I was heading that way too. I was glad I didn’t go to prison myself. I was getting crazy, too, and he stopped me a couple times. [unclear] rob some people, I guess. I don’t remember.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Rob some people?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, grabbed a knife [unclear].

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: You did?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, I cut somebody up [unclear]. Man, woman, I didn’t care. [unclear] money is all. Yeah, I would’ve killed them, so I testified against him. [unclear].

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Who was going to—

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Well, I was going to slit their throat.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: You were going to set—

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, slit their throat.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Oh, my gosh.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Man, woman.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Whoever had the money.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: [unclear] my brother. Yeah, well, he said, “Hey, grab me a knife.” [unclear] whatever. That was on Sixth and Union. We used to call it the pink house, the pink palace. It was all pink, this [unclear] little apartment. My sister used to live [unclear] back in the day. I don’t know what year that was.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: How long did you live like that? How many years was that?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Until I sobered up, 1982. I was [unclear] program to program.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: So at least from the 1970s to 1982, that kind of life?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, early eighties, I finally sobered up. I remember because I walked down here. Wilshire, [unclear]? I was going to jump off. I was waiting for a big Mack truck to hit, and I was sober too. I remember that.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: You were going to jump off the bridge?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, commit suicide. I was by myself.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: What happened?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Then the trucks started coming on the other side. Had to walk to the other side. I was waiting for an eighteen-wheeler. I don’t want to bounce all over the freeway. I wanted to get squashed like a cockroach, I guess. My brother came over [unclear] DTs and I was, like, hearing voices—

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Oh, my god.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: —hearing music. I kept hearing that “Get Down Tonight,” K.C. and the Sunshine Band. It was real clear. I could just hear it and I told my brother, I said, “Hey, can you hear that music? They’re playing good music.” “I don’t hear nothing.”

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Oh, dear.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: I’d hear the voice of people talking. This was during the day. I thought it only happened at night. I was on the DTs. That’s when I sobered up. I remember that [unclear].

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Did you go to a program then? What program did you go to for—

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Main Artery. No, I went to the Men’s Lodge too. I bounced all over the place, the Main Artery.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Did they help you? Did those programs help you?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, but I guess I didn’t want to sober up. I just wanted to [unclear] dry up or be on the wagon for a while and get my health back, and then go back out there again, do it again. I remember that. Wayne Fanning, that was the name of it.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: What was it?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Wayne Fanning. It’s a detox in El Monte.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: But you just went from program to program, you said. Men’s Lodge, Main Artery.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: And [unclear], used to be the Royal Palms—no, Mary Lind.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Mary who?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Mary Lind Foundation. That’s an alcohol program. Royal Palms and [unclear]. Used to be right here downtown. Yeah, it was real fancy, got your own room, your own key. I remember that, because I didn’t want guys to see me cry, so I had to close the door and cry in the pillow, telling god [unclear] leave. I don’t know. “Lift this curse from me,” or whatever. All of a sudden, it just went away.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Just like that?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, I didn’t want to drink no more. I didn’t see no bright light or nothing. I mean, the door was open a little. I had to close it when I started crying. I was sober in there. Man, I was shaking. Oh, man, but I got over that. Ever since then, I’ve been sober.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Really? You’ve never—

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Never drank nothing. I’ve been offered. A couple times I got tempted, but I would walk away or—well, I had to walk away. Shit, if I would stay longer, I know I would have took that drink. Am I ten years sober now? That was 1990. That’s when I was going to school here to get my GED.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Diploma?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: No, my GED in 1990. That’s when I stopped drinking. I was sober, like, eight years then.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Wow, that’s wonderful.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: [unclear]. [unclear] a lot of people die, just pass away due to drinking. My older sister had cirrhosis. I had to bury her at Rose Hills. I go visit her every now and then.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: That’s your sister, you said?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, my older. My other brother got killed in a car wreck. Oh, man, that was real hard for me. That was in 1988, in November, a couple days before Thanksgiving, he was killed. I guess it was his fault. I don’t know. The guy, I guess, that he was working with, construction or something, I guess he wasn’t buckled in there, safety belt, seat belt. I guess the guy was falling asleep driving. Don’t know where they were driving to. That was in Utah [unclear]. I guess the car started to flip and he fell off. I mean he fell asleep and he went in that ravine or whatever. It started flipping. He went outside the windshield. That was real hard for me.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: You’ve had a really rough life, LeRoy, in Los Angeles.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: You’ve been sober for twenty-some years at least.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, twenty, yeah.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Twenty, almost thirty years.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Twenty-five.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: You said ’82.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: 1982. That was in May.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: This is 2011. Yeah, twenty-nine years.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: My other brother, he’s been sober longer than me, Ralph. He lives in Wisconsin. He comes to visit here. We get along. He’s been sober for awhile, too, Frank. I remember he had a hell of a life, go to jail and everything. I didn’t want to go to jail, like, sixty days or something like that. Man, he was doing that. Oh, man. He saw me, “Hey, you related to Big Soldier?” I said, “Yeah, that’s my brother.” “Oh, man,” he said. “I don’t want to see you in here again.” Oh, that’s another thing that sobered me up because I didn’t want to go to jail, revolving door. I remember that. That judge [unclear], he didn’t like drunks either because his daughter got killed by a drunken driver.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Nobody likes drunken drivers.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: No, that judge. That’s another thing he didn’t like, drunks. “I see you in here again, Mr. Big Soldier, I’m going to give you ninety days.” He said, “I’m going to let you go this time. You’re lucky.” My bailiff or whatever, he says, “I’m going to go get a release.” That’s the time I sobered up. I remember that, yeah, in ’82, in May, I guess. I said I’d go to detox. Before I did that, that’s when I thought I was going to jump off the freeway. I remember that. Yeah, you don’t forget something like that. I remember like it happened yesterday. I was sober and everything. That’s when my brother said, “We have got a live one here.” I remember that. So many guys, they came from another [unclear]—I don’t know if that was Sioux or what, but we always hang around a lot of Sioux. [unclear] Sioux. That’s when I’d hang out over there, I think. We had all the tribes, Pima and everything, Kiowa and all that, Chippewa, Choctaw. There was a lot of Siouxs over there, I mean back in the day, I mean, at the Moulin Rouge.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: At the bars?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah. That went on for a while, I guess.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: It sounds like you had a rough time, and your brothers and sisters had a rough time, your family. How was it for your parents? How did they do? Did they start drinking, too, or were they able to—

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: My dad used to slap my mom and everything.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: So he would abuse your mother?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: He was drinking?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: In ’63, I remember that. He almost threw her out the window one time.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Oh, gosh.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: We had to stop him. My sister was—I think she had some friends over. I don’t quite remember. I don’t know if I got traumatized with it or what. I don’t remember. I remember that he was going to throw her out the window, and the cops came, took him to jail. Of course, we forgave him like nothing had happened. [unclear] the place that we moved to, yeah, because they were drinking. There would be fighting and everything. Yeah, he died due to drinking too. My mom passed away first. She had cirrhosis. I don’t remember the year. I [unclear] her death certificate. I never done that. [unclear] my dad too, because my mom passed away first. [unclear] was working at the Indian Center, yeah. Had to be ’75.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: What did she die of?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Cirrhosis.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: So she was drinking as well?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, looked like she was pregnant. You big in the belly, look like you’re pregnant.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Swollen.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: It burst or whatever. She died that day, or that night, I guess. Took her to the hospital. She looked like she was sober. “I’ll see you guys later,” and gave her a hug and kiss and everything. That was the last time I saw her. [unclear] bad luck. They want to send my mom back home, Indian burial, back to Wisconsin. She’s back over there like my dad, too, when he passed away. We sent him back. [unclear] the service, the army, they pay for everything. He was in the service. They’ll pay for everything because he’s a veteran, so that was good news.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Yeah, that helped.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: I never went back. I regret that too.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: You never went back to Wisconsin?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: My mom and dad was buried out there. I don’t know. I should have went back with them, took the body back. We never did. [unclear] drinking ways, whatever.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Yeah, it’s hard to make those kinds of decisions when you’re drinking, isn’t it?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, when you got a hangover or—

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: When you were growing up as a boy, did you ever go back to Wisconsin to visit?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Never went back home. No, not yet.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: What about your parents? Of course, prior to passing away, did they ever go back to Wisconsin and visit?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: No, never.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: So as you were growing up then, you lived a lot of different places, went to a lot of different schools. What did you think about yourself, about being Indian? You always knew you were Indian, I guess, is that right?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Oh, yeah. Oh, yeah. [unclear] to be Indian, yeah. Yeah, it was rough, I guess. I mean, back in the seventies, [unclear] Wounded Knee and all that, and AIM. Oh, man, that was another thing the cops didn’t like.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Here in L.A.?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, [unclear] AIM. [unclear] like a militant, like a Black Panther. You’re like a terrorist, I guess. I don’t know. That’s what they’ll say. I remember that.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: So the cops would let you know that they didn’t like AIM.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: The LAPD [Los Angeles Police Department]. I heard that. That’s what I heard. They said, “[unclear].” [unclear] was claiming he was AIM, but he wasn’t.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Who was this?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Some Indian guy. They beat him up. They beat the shit out of him.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Oh, my god. Police did that?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah. And that’s that a cop, that cop that didn’t like Indians at all. I don’t know. Something happened to his daughter or sister. She got raped or assaulted by some Indians. Oh, man, he didn’t like Indians at all. One of my brothers beat the shit out of him in the alley. I remember that. He told me that. [unclear] white guy. [unclear]. He says, “I’m tired of your goddamn ass. I heard you’re a bad ass on the street,” and all that. My brother said he was [unclear], said, “We’re going to settle this shit once and for all,” and he took the handcuffs off, took his belt off, the cop. My brother, he beat the shit out of him.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Your brother beat the cop up?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah. Well, I guess he got so much of the—yeah, Indian guy beat him up or something like that. I guess he quit or resigned LAPD. He was a sergeant too. I remember that. God, that was [unclear]. He didn’t like cops at all. We used to be drinking at MacArthur Park.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Your brother?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: All of us. [unclear] bottles [unclear]. They wasn’t even open. He’ll break them just for the hell of it.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Who would do that? Who would break them?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: That cop, that sergeant.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: They were just harassing you then.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, they couldn’t do nothing. [unclear] sergeant, [unclear] do to him. He’s going to lie anyway. They’ll take his word against ours. We’re drunks and lowlife, I guess. I heard that term before, lowlife or whatever. “Ain’t gonna amount to nothing. You guys have to sober up.” I don’t know. Just growing up in L.A. I don’t know, just being sober, I guess, you go through hard times, but you’ve got to deal with it.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: When you were growing up, did you have any friends in school just to hang around with or play or go to their house or go on bike rides or something?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Oh, yeah. Yeah, hike around in [unclear] Park. Yeah, [unclear] as far as I know.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: When you were growing up, did you use any of the Indian services, your family? You said the church used to come and pick you up, take you to church. What about the Indian Center? Did your parents go down there for assistance in any way?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Services?

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Yeah, services.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: I don’t know.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: You don’t remember that?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: I don’t remember.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Because they would have something to help you.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: My dad was working, so I guess—their friends and that used to help us out, give us some money or whatever for food.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Did you have a car, too, though, your dad?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: He knew how to drive, but he didn’t drive that much. My mom too. I guess she knew how to drive, too, but she never—we never got around to that, to a car, and because she didn’t like driving in the city too. Out there in the back roads, [unclear].

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Yeah, that’s another thing. Right.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Oh, yeah, I mean, he knew how to drive.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Where did you go when you or the kids or your parents or someone got sick? Where did you go for healthcare?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: The county, at USC. Oh, yeah, my dad was working at—he was working a long time too. Custodian.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: At the county?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, making good money over there. We’d go visit him, too, on the bus, RTD downtown. I forgot what line that was. We’d go visit him.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: You and your mother and brothers and sisters?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: I was sober. Yeah, I used to go visit him, sober for once. He’d stay on the wagon for a while, like, three, four months. Of course, he started drinking again. Man, but he always made it to work though, hangover or not. Yeah, it’s good money.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: How long did he work there?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: I don’t know. I forgot. I mean, it was a long time. Five years, probably longer than that. Worked there for a while. I don’t know if he got laid off. I think he did get laid off. Something happened. I don’t know. Oh, yeah, that’s when he started working over at—oh, no, that was after that Triple-A. Sixty-three? Late seventies. Sixties, I guess.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: So it sounds like your dad could find jobs. He was able to find jobs and stay working, as you said, even though he’d go to work hungover sometimes. But he was able to, at least, keep working, right?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: A working drunk. That’s what they call it in the program. When you need the money, you stay sober. I’ve done that myself when I was at work, have a hangover, but I’d go to work anyway. I need the money for payday and drink, party with some women friends of mine. Yeah, I remember those days.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: That was a pretty hard life. You’ve had a pretty hard life, LeRoy, but you’re doing much better now.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Oh, yeah. I stay sober.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Stay sober and you’ve got friends, right? You’ve got some friends out there. I saw you talking to a couple of people.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Oh, yeah, I got a lot of friends, yeah, a lot of people I didn’t like either when I was sobering up. A lot of them are dead now. All the ones I didn’t like, they’re all dead and gone or back in prison.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Oh, gosh.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Or looney tunes, insane or something. I don’t know what word you call that, state hospital.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Just a few more questions, LeRoy. We don’t have much more, but I’m interested in how you—you seem to have had a lot of Indian friends and you stayed in the community, the Indian community. You were drinking quite a bit, I realize that, but what was the Indian community like here other than the drinking community? Did you ever have any contact with just the sober people that had a different lifestyle, or was most of your life spent in the drinking community or partying?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: [unclear], mostly, [unclear] stay sober, going down the wrong path or whatever. We’re going to die. That’s the first thing they said, “You’ve got to sober up. You’re too young to die,” whatever. Because I’ve seen a lot of friends die like that. [unclear] sober up, [unclear] all your friends or whatever. I know one guy did that. That’s what I heard. He got mangled up pretty bad, but he killed his brothers and sisters.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: That’s terrible.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: I thank god I never got into drugs. I smoked weed and that, but thank god. I was offered a lot of heroin and PCP. Thank god, I never took that. That drinking’s bad enough. I turned wino and everything. But my dad and mom, [unclear] nothing to drink and they hadn’t cared for wine that much. But, boy, a hangover, and I seen I don’t know how many bottles in there, like, four, five bottles [unclear]. That’s what he used to drink, Gallo.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: This was your dad?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah. [unclear] some wine in there [unclear]. To hell with it. In the morning, they won’t get their checks, SSI and all that. My dad was in the army and that, army pension or what—and [unclear]. We started drinking their wine, turn wino. Yeah, that was bad. It wasn’t that bad. We didn’t like the taste, but when I had a hangover, I didn’t care. I remember that.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Well, those are really all the questions that I have, or things that I brought to cover, LeRoy, what you remember about relocation, the project or your family coming, or anybody that’s talked about it or mentioned it, or anybody else that you knew that came out on it. What is your overall impression, do you think, of the relocation program?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: From out here?

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Coming out here?

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Yeah, coming out here and working and the whole program. You think it was a good thing? You think it worked and helped, or do you think it was something else?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Coming back out here. [unclear] my sister when she was born. That’s when we came out here. Me and my mom and dad and—my sister because I know she was born out there. Dang. Yeah, she had to be born out there. The rest of the other brothers and sisters, they lived out here. I mean, they were born out here.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Let me ask you something. Were your parents already drinking quite a bit when they came out here already?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: I think so, yeah.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Do you think you would have had a different life if you’d stayed in Wisconsin?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: I don’t think so. Everybody was drinking back there. Everybody was dying out there.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: And there was no work, you said.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah. And snow. Yeah, that was another thing. So they say, “Go to sunny California, L.A. You have to go to L.A. Los Angeles, [unclear], way better.” Yet there was the earthquake, so—

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: And the riots.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah. Yeah, but I liked it. They liked it out there. That’s why we came out here, back in those days.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Your parents never went back to Wisconsin to visit?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: They always said they were going to visit, but they don’t save up and that. Or they want to take us back there, too, to visit our relative. We got a lot of relatives. It never came about, never did.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: So you have a whole community back there that you never got a chance to know.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, I got a sister living out there. My brother, he’s been out there, like, ten, twelve years now, but they’re working in the casino.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: That’s good. Have you ever thought about trying to go back there and find work?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, I was going to go out there. He told me I could move out there. I was going to do that a couple years ago. I was going to live with my brother.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: And then what happened? How come you didn’t go?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: I changed my mind. No, no, I found work out here. What was I doing? I was doing security. That didn’t last. I don’t know. I just got bored with it. No, that’s when I got injured, hurt my leg. I was working at night, graveyard. I slipped and fell and broke my ankle [unclear], my kneecap. I didn’t see these—they had these [unclear] like a gas station. I was security guard there, working eleven to seven or ten to six or something like that.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Night shift, then.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, I had a flashlight and everything. I didn’t watch where I stepped. I slipped on those little pipes. Boy, I went up in the air. Boom! I didn’t think nothing of it.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: You came down on your knee.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, my right knee here. It was all puffed up. Boy, that hurt. I called them. I told that supervisor. He said, “Oh, man, you should have got a lawyer, man. You should have sued their asses for that, man. They’re supposed to take you to the hospital right there. And you showed them?” I said, “Yeah, my whole knee was all puffed up like that, and he just wrote it down.” “Okay” And he just walked away. “Okay, you go home now.’” “Oh, man, that ain’t right. You got to get a lawyer, [unclear].”

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Did you sue then? You never sued?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: No, the following day, that’s when I told him. He looked at my leg, the supervisor, because I had the key. I couldn’t work. I told him, “My one knee’s messed up.” I told him, “I fell down accidentally.” I told the supervisor. He wrote it down in that log. “Better get him to the hospital or he can sue us.” “They should have taken you right then and there, worker’s comp.” So I got workers’ comp, like, six months. So I just stayed home, got a check. I didn’t work or nothing.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Did you have surgery on your knee?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: No. They paid for it.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: It just got better on its own?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: That was good.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: So I was off six months, workers’ comp. I had to go back to work again. They give me the runaround and, “Oh, we haven’t found nothing for you. Just be patient.” That went on for months. I told them, “I can go back to work Monday.” It was healed up then, but he couldn’t find no work. I remember that. Yeah, I almost went out there that one time. He was going to fly me there. I never been on a plane either. I’ve been in a helicopter and that. [unclear]. I like to fly up. He would pay for my bus, my plane.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Plane ticket?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah. “Stay out here with me.”

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Get a job, right?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: He said, “I’ll get you a job in there.” He said, “I guarantee you’ll get hired,” They want to hire you. They hired other people, minorities, but they try to hire our own tribe and that.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Yeah, your own community member. Never thought of doing that anymore?

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: No. I was going to just work out there, but they’re going to put those five more, I hear. They’ll have, like, nine casinos up there. Already got four now, I think. Five more? He said, “That’s what they’re saying, right out there, I guess.” Chicago, Illinois. That didn’t go through, I guess. That’s going to be the biggest casino, way bigger than the one in Las Vegas. That’s what I heard.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Wow.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Where they got to nine?

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: There might be some opportunities for you there then.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: Yeah, Chicago. I think it got turned down. They didn’t want us over there—

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Oh.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: —because Las Vegas, they don’t like us, the Indians—

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Yeah, they’re taking away some of the business.

sp.speaker: BIG SOLDIER
sp.p: I know because the Indians out in California, everybody [unclear]. Yeah, they’re all doing good. They’re going to Las Vegas. They’re giving away money, cars in there. That’s what they do in Wisconsin, too, give money away.

sp.speaker: BAYHYLLE
sp.p: Well, LeRoy, those are all the questions that I have. I’m going to turn the machine off now. [End of interview]
